I was present when Gilroy was searched—Stingimore searched him, and he has got the money with the exception of the gold—he can give you exact evidence as to the money found—I only found one counterfeit coin on Seabrook—the last train leaves Dorking for London on the South-Eastern line about half-past 9, and on the London, Brighton, and South Coast about 5 minutes to 10 at night—I know the potman at the Bull's Head—I know that the landlady and the mother sent the potman out on this evening, but do not know at what time—I did not see him come out—I saw the potman in the High Street between 10 o'clock and the time that Gilroy was taken in custody—I did not see him in a public-house treating Gilroy to something to drink—I do not know that the potman was in Gilroy's company at all—I do not know that he gave him something to drink, and that he went from there home to the bed which he had engaged.

JOHN STINGIMORE . I am a police-constable of Dorking—on the night of the 8th of September I was sent to the Three Tuns Inn about 11 o'clock, and saw the prisoner Gilroy there in bed—I said "I want you on a charge of uttering counterfeit coin"—he said "I know nothing about it"—I asked him to get up—he put on his things and went with me to the station—I searched him both there and at the station, and found 3l. 14s. 8d.—there was 1 sovereign, 2 half sovereigns, 2 florins, 13 shillings, 36 sixpences, 1 threepenny piece, and 4s. 5d. in bronze, all good money—the public-houses close at 11 o'clock.

Cross-examined. I took Gilroy to Mrs. Butler at the Bull's Head to be identified—I asked her if she knew him—there are about 9,000 people in Dorking and there is one superintendent and four policemen to look after the 9,000—these depositions were taken at the Dorking Police-court.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am one of the inspectors of coin to Her Majesty's Hint—these coins are all bad and from the same mould.

By the JURY. I arrive at that conclusion because these counterfeit pieces are cast in a plaster-of-Paris mould from a good coin, which is termed the pattern piece, and all its imperfections are reproduced in the copies—they are of course all of the same date—I am not bound to point out in open Court where the imperfections are, but I can see them with my naked eye.
Cross-examined. You will find the date on the obverse side.
GUILTY .

99.
EDWARD GILROY (38) was again indicted, with
HENRY SEABROOK (23)
, for unlawfully uttering a counterfeit florin to
Mary Ann Butler, another to
Ann Newman, and another to
Harriet Booking. MR. BAGGALLAY Prosecuted; MR. THORNS COLE, who defended Gilroy, withdrew from the case in consequence of the former verdict.
WILLIAM WALTON . The evidence given by this witness in the last case was read over to. him from the short-hand writer's notes, to which he assented.
Cross-examined by Seabrook. I can swear that you were with your fellow-prisoner.
HARRIET BOOKING . The evidence of this witness was read over to her, to which she assented.

Cross-examined by Seabrook. It was nearly half past nine when you called at our house but not not quite—I did not find that the coin was bad till Superintendent Lambert came in, and asked if I had taken any bad coin—that was at 10 o'clock or shortly after—no one was with you but Gilroy.

MARY ANN BUTLER , The evidence of this witness was read over to her, to which she assented, and added: I gave Gilroy If. 9d. change—when I handed Seabrook the florin I said, "It is bad money, give me a good one "—I didnot notice that he made any reply, but he handed me a good shilling end I gave him tenpence change.

By the COURT. I know the coin was bad because I felt it very greasy in my fingers and I did not put it in the till, till I had said to a person in the bar "This is a bad one, is it not?" and he said "A very bad one" in the prisoner's presence—I did not ring it, but he threw it on the counter himself—it did not sound much because it is a pewter counter.
Cross-examined by Seabrook. When I was asked if I could recognise you I did not Say that I could not swear to you.
ANN NEWMAN . The evidence of this witness was read over to her, to which she assented.

Cross-examined by Seabrook. I did not find out that the coin was bad till I was told so by Superintendent Lambert about 25 minutes or half past ten—you were in company with Gilroy when you called at oar house.
GEORGE LAMBERT . The evidence of this witness was read over, to which is assented.
Cross-examined by Seabrook. When I arrested you, I took you to the landlady where you passed the coin—I asked her if you were one of the men, and she said "Yes."

Seabrook's Defence. I arrived at Dorking by myself—I do not know the prisoner charged with me—I know nothing about passing these coins—the last coin found on me was returned by the lady, and I wrapped it up in paper—if I had known it was bad I should hare thrown it away.

GUILTY . GILROY was further charged (on the first Indictment) with a previous conviction at this Court in the name of
Thomas Parsons of feloniously uttering counterfeit coin in November, 1875; to this he PLEADED GUILTY. GILROY**.—
Six Years' Penal Servitude. SEABROOK.—
Fifteen Months Hard Labour.

100.
ANNIE BURNS (40)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

MESSRS. POLAND and MATHEWS Prosecuted. JAKE SUTTON. I am assistant to Mr. Clarke at the refreshment bar, Waterloo Station—on 29th August I served the prisoner with a Bath bun, price twopence—she gave me a half-crown—I put it in the tester, bent it, and gave it back to her, and she gave me a good florin and left—on the next day she came again to another bar where I was serving, and was served with a glass of ale—she tendered this shilling—I put it in the tester, and found it was bad—I gave it to Mr. Hopgood.

MARGARET GREGG . I am a barmaid at Waterloo Station—on 12th September the prisoner came and asked for a glass of milk, which cams to twopence—she paid with a florin, and 1s. 10d. change was given her—the florin was put in the till—there were no other florins there—I afterwards examined it, found it was bad, and gave it to Miss Seal, who gave it back to the prisoner, and the prisoner gave back the change and paid for what she had—I have no doubt she is the person.

ELIZABETH SEAL . I am a barmaid at Waterloo Station—on 12th September the prisoner, I believe, but I won't swear to her, had some milk, and paid me with a florin—I put it in the till—there were no other florins there, only small silver—Miss Gregg afterwards took it out and handed it to the prisoner.

CHARLES HOPGOOD . I am manager to Mr. Clarke at Waterloo Station—on 10th October this shilling was given to me—I fetched a constable, who spoke to the prisoner—I did not near what she said—I gave him the shilling and said to her" You have been trying to pass bad money, and I am afraid this is not the first time"—she said,' 'I know nothing about it." RICHARD EDMUNDS. I am a detective employed by the London and South-Western Railway—Mr. Hopgood took me to the prisoner and showed me this shilling—I told her I should detain her till a metropolitan?
constable was fetched, and she would be charged with uttering a bad shilling—she made no reply—I handed her over to Warren with the shilling.

WILLIAM WARREN (Policeman). I took the prisoner and received this shilling—she said that she was not aware it was bad—a gentleman gave it to her the previous night with 10s.—on the way to the station she took a good florin from her pocket—a good half-crown and shilling were found in her purse—Mrs. Sutton said in the prisoner's hearing that she was there some days before and tendered bad money, the prisoner made no reply.
MR. JOHN WEBSTER , This shilling is bad.
The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. "I know nothing about it; I received it from a gentleman the night before with some other silver."
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, DECEMBER 1 ST, 1882.
